DataElement.preferredName: Study Subject TNM Staging System Category

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A matter or an individual that is observed, analyzed, examined, investigated, experimented upon, or/and treated in the course of a particular study._A system for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A matter or person that is analyzed, examined, investigated, experimented upon, or treated in the course of particular study.

Concepts.definition: A matter or an individual that is observed, analyzed, examined, investigated, experimented upon, or/and treated in the course of a particular study.

Property.preferredDefinition: A system of clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.

Concepts.definition: A system for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.origin: AMC CRF:AIDS Malignancy Consortium Case Report Form
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Curated for AMC S005 protocol DC

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A system for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

Concepts.definition: One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

Concepts.definition: One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A system for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.:A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
